textdata: STATE OF FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH  DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH,  PETITIONER, Vv. CASE NO. 2021-02159 RUBEN GAMEZ, M.D.,  RESPONDENT.  / ADMINISTRATIVE COMPLAINT  Petitioner, Department of Health, by and through its undersigned counsel, hereby files this Administrative Complaint before the Board of Medicine against Respondent, Ruben Gamez, M.D., and in support thereof  alleges:  1. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of medicine pursuant to section 20.43, Florida Statutes; chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed physician within the state of Florida, having been issued the license  number of ME110644.  Page 1 of 8 DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159 3. | Respondent's address of record is 99 Yorktown, Newport Beach, California 92660.  4. Respondent is also licensed to practice medicine in the state of California by the Medical Board of California, the licensing authority charged with regulating the practice of medicine in California.  5. | Onor about November 19, 2019, Respondent’s guilty plea to one (1) count of violating section 245(a)(1) of the California Penal Code (assault with a deadly weapon), a felony, was accepted by the Superior Court of California, County of Orange.  6. | The personal qualities essential to the sound practice of medicine include integrity, respect for the public trust, good judgment, and respect for the well-being of others.  7. Respondent's actions reflect poor judgement; a violation of both the trust of his patients and the trusts society places in physicians; and a lack of respect for the well-being of others.  8. | Under these circumstances, Respondent’s accepted guilty plea for assault with a deadly weapon, a felony, constitutes a crime which relates  to the practice of or the ability to practice medicine.  Page 2 of 8  DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159 9. On or about February 5, 2021, the Medical Board of California acted against Respondent’s California medical license via a Stipulated Settlement and Disciplinary Order (Order) which revoked Respondent's California medical license, with the revocation stayed until completion of seven (7) years’ probation in compliance with the terms and conditions of the Order.  10. Respondent did not notify the Board of Medicine, in writing within 30 days, of the disciplinary action that the Medical Board of California took against his license on or about February 5, 2021.  11. Respondent failed to report the acceptance of his guilty plea by the Superior Court of California, County of Orange, on or about November 19, 2019, in writing, within 30 days, to the Board of Medicine.  COUNT ONE Violation of Section 458.331(1)(c), Florida Statutes (2019)  12. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through eight (8), as if fully set forth herein.  13. Section 458.331(1)(c), Florida Statutes (2019), provides that being convicted or found guilty of, or entering a plea of nolo contendere to, regardless of adjudication, a crime in any jurisdiction which directly relates  Page 3 of 8  DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159 to the practice of medicine or the ability to practice medicine constitutes grounds for disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine.  14. Onor about November 19, 2019, the Superior Court of California, County of Orange, accepted Respondent's guilty plea to one count of felony assault with a deadly weapon.  15. Based on the foregoing, Respondent violated section 458.331(1)(c), Florida Statutes (2019).  COUNT TWO Violation of Section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes (2020)  16. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through nine (9), as if fully set forth herein.  17. Section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes (2020), sets forth grounds for disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine and provides that having a license or the authority to practice medicine revoked, suspended, or otherwise acted against, including denial of licensure, by the licensing authority of another jurisdiction constitutes grounds for discipline.  18. The Medical Board of California imposed an Order against Respondent's license on or about February 5, 2021.  19. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes (2020).  Page 4of 8  DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159 COUNT THREE Violation of Section 458.331(1)(kk), Florida Statutes (2020)  20. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through ten (10).  21. Section 458.331(1)(kk), Florida Statutes (2020), provides that failing to report to the Board of Medicine, in writing, within 30 days, when action, as defined in section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes, is taken against one’s license to practice as a physician in another state, territory, or country, constitutes grounds for discipline by the Board of Medicine.  22. Respondent failed to report the February 5, 2021, disciplinary action taken against his license by the Medical Board of California, in writing to the Board of Medicine within 30 days of such action.  23. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated section 458.331(1)(kk), Florida Statutes (2020).  COUNT FOUR Violation of Section 456.072(1)(x), Florida Statutes (2019)  24. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through eleven (11). 25. Pursuant to Section 456.072(1)(x), Florida Statutes (2019),  failure to report to the Board of Medicine, in writing within 30 days, after the  Page 5 of 8  DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159 licensee has been convicted or found guilty of a crime in any jurisdiction constitutes grounds for discipline by the Board of Medicine.  26. Respondent failed to report the acceptance of his guilty plea by the Superior Court of California, County of Orange, on or about November 19, 2019, in writing within 30 days, to the Board of Medicine.  27. Based on the foregoing, Respondent violated section  456.072(1)(x), Florida Statutes (2019).  WHEREFORE, the Petitioner respectfully requests that the Board of Medicine enter an order imposing one or more of the following penalties: permanent revocation or suspension of Respondent's license, restriction of practice, imposition of an administrative fine, issuance of a reprimand, placement of Respondent on probation, corrective action, refund of fees billed or collected, remedial education and/or any other relief that the Board  deems appropriate.  [ Signature page follows.]|  Page 6 of 8  DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159 SIGNED this 25th day of October, 2021.  FILED  DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH DEPUTY CLERK  CLERK: (imme Mound  DATE:___gey 2.5 2021  KMS/In  PCP: October 22, 2021  Joseph Ladapo, MD, PhD State Surgeon General  Kristi Suarey  Kristin Suarez  Assistant General Counsel  DOH Prosecution Services Unit 4052 Bald Cypress Way, Bin C-65 Tallahassee, Florida 32399-3265 Florida Bar Number 1028039 (850) 558 - 9878 Telephone (850) 245 - 4683 Facsimile  PCP Members: Gary Dolin, M.D.; Luz Marina Pages, M.D.  DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159  Page 7 of 8 NOTICE OF RIGHTS  Respondent has the right to request a hearing to be conducted in accordance with Section 120.569 and 120.57, Florida Statutes, to be represented by counsel or other qualified representative, to present evidence and argument, to call and cross-examine witnesses and to have subpoena and subpoena duces tecum issued on his or her behalf if a hearing is requested. A request or petition for an administrative hearing must be in writing and must be received by the Department within 21 days from the day Respondent received the Administrative Complaint, pursuant to Rule 28-106.111(2), Florida Administrative Code. If Respondent fails to request a hearing within 21 days of receipt of this Administrative Complaint, Respondent waives the right to request a hearing on the facts alleged in this Administrative Complaint pursuant to Rule 28-106.111(4), Florida Administrative Code. Any request for an administrative proceeding to challenge or contest the material facts or charges contained in the Administrative Complaint must conform to Rule 28-106.2015(5), Florida Administrative Code.  Please be advised that mediation under Section 120.573, Florida Statutes, is not available for administrative disputes involving this agency action.  NOTICE REGARDING ASSESSMENT OF COSTS  Respondent is placed on notice that Petitioner has incurred costs related to the investigation and prosecution of this matter. Pursuant to Section 456.072(4), Florida Statutes, the Board shall assess costs related to the investigation and prosecution of a disciplinary matter, which may include attorney hours and costs, on the Respondent in addition any other discipline imposed.  Page 8 of 8  DOH v. Ruben Gamez, M.D. Case Number 2021-02159

By:  Deputy Agency Clerk  STATE OF FLORIDA BOARD OF MEDICINE  DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, Petitioner, vs. DOH CASE NO.: 2021-34814 LICENSE NO.: ME0083014  MARK ANTONIO HERNANDEZ, M.D.,  Respondent.  /  FINAL ORDER  THIS CAUSE came before the BOARD OF MEDICINE (Board) pursuant to Sections 120.569 and 120.57(2), Florida Statutes, on June 3, 2022, in Orlando, Florida, for consideration of the Administrative Complaint (attached hereto as Exhibit A) in the above-styled cause pursuant to Respondent’s Blection of Rights. At the hearing, Petitioner was represented by Kristen Summers, Chief Legal Counsel. Respondent was not present and was not represented by counsel. The facts are not in dispute.  Upon consideration, it is ORDERED:  1. The allegations of fact set forth in the Administrative Complaint are approved and adopted and incorporated herein by reference as the findings of fact by the Board.  2. The conclusions of law alleged and set forth in the  Administrative Complaint are approved and adopted and  Ll incorporated herein by reference as the conclusions of law by the Board.  3. The violations set forth warrant disciplinary action by the Board. THEREFORE, IT IS HEREBY ORDERED AND ADJUDGED:  Respondent’s license to practice medicine in the State of  Florida is hereby REVOKED.  RULING ON MOTION TO ASSESS COSTS At the Hearing on this matter, Petitioner waived its Motion to Assess Costs associated with this matter. (NOTH: SEE RULE 64B8-8.0011, FLORIDA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE. UNLESS  OTHERWISE SPECIFIED BY FINAL ORDER, THE RULE SETS FORTH THE  REQUIREMENTS FOR PERFORMANCE OF ALL PENALTIES CONTAINED IN THIS FINAL  ORDER. )  This Final Order shall take effect upon being filed with the Clerk of the Department of Health. DONE AND ORDERED this 16th day of June , 2022. BOARD OF MEDICINE  Paul A. Vazquez  Paul A. Vazquez (Jun 16, 2022 10:36 EDT) Paul A. Vazquez, J.D., Executive Director For David A. REVIEW PROCEEDINGS ARE GOVERNED BY THE FLORIDA RULES OF APPELLATE PROCEDURE. SUCH PROCEEDINGS ARE COMMENCED BY FILING ONE COPY OF A NOTICE OF APPEAL WITH THE AGENCY CLERK OF THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND A SECOND COPY, ACCOMPANIED BY FILING FEES PRESCRIBED BY LAW, WITH THE DISTRICT COURT OF APPEAL, FIRST DISTRICT, OR WITH THE DISTRICT COURT OF APPEAL IN THE APPELLATE DISTRICT WHERE THE PARTY RESIDES. THE NOTICE OF APPEAL MUST BE FILED WITHIN THIRTY (30) DAYS OF RENDITION OF THE ORDER TO BE REVIEWED. DOH CASE NO, 2021-34814 MARK HERNANDEZ, M.D.,  RESPONDENT. /  ADMINISTRATIVE COMPLAINT  Petitioner, Department of Health, by and through its undersigned counsel, files this Administrative Complaint before the Board of Medicine against Respondent, Mark Hernandez, M.D., and in support thereof alleges:  1. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of medicine in the state of Florida pursuant to section 20.43, Florida Statutes; chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed physician within the state of Florida, having been issued license number ME83014.  3. Respondent's address of record is 10645 Hammocks Blvd., #717,  Miami, Florida 33196. 14148  4. On or about August 16, 2021, Respondent pled guilty in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida to one count of conspiracy to commit health care and wire fraud, in violation of 18 U.S.C. section 1349.  5. Section 456.072(1)(Il), Florida Statutes (2019), subjects a licensee to discipline for being convicted of, or entering a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to, any misdemeanor or felony, regardless of adjudication, a crime in any jurisdiction which relates to health care fraud.  6. | Respondent entered a plea of guilty to conspiracy to commit health care and wire fraud, which is a crime that is related to health care fraud.  7. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated section 456.072(1)(Il), Florida Statutes, by being convicted of, regardless of adjudication, a crime in any jurisdiction which relates to health care fraud.  WHEREFORE, the Petitioner respectfully requests that the Board of Medicine enter an order imposing one or more of the following penalties: permanent revocation or suspension of Respondent's license, restriction of practice, imposition of an administrative fine, issuance of a reprimand, placement of Respondent on probation, corrective action, refund of fees  Page 2 of 4  DOH v. Hernandez MD DOH Case No. 2021-34814  a 14149  billed or collected, remedial education and/or any other relief that the Board deems appropriate.  SIGNED this __ 21% day of_January 2022.  Joseph A. Hernandez MD DOH Case No. 2021-34814  a 14150  NOTICE OF RIGHTS  Respondent has the right to request a hearing to be conducted in accordance with Sections 120.569 and 120.57, Florida Statutes, to be represented by counsel or other qualified representative, to present evidence and argument, to call and cross-examine witnesses and to have subpoena and subpoena duces tecum issued on his or her behalf if a hearing is requested.  A request or petition for an administrative hearing must be in writing and must be received by the Department within 21 days from the day Respondent received the Administrative Complaint, pursuant to Rule 28- 106.111(2), Florida Administrative Code. If Respondent fails to request a hearing within 21 days of receipt of this Administrative Complaint, Respondent waives the right to request a hearing on the facts alleged in this Administrative Complaint pursuant to Rule 28-106.111(4), Florida Administrative Code. Any request for an administrative proceeding to challenge or contest the material facts or charges contained in the Administrative Complaint must conform to Rule 28-106.2015(5), Florida Administrative Code.  Mediation under Section 120.573, Florida Statutes, is not available to resolve this Administrative Complaint.  NOTICE REGARDING ASSESSMENT OF COSTS  Respondent is placed on notice that Petitioner has incurred costs related to the investigation and prosecution of this matter. Pursuant to Section 456.072(4), Florida Statutes, the Board shall assess costs related to the investigation and prosecution of a disciplinary matter, which may include attorney hours and costs, on the Respondent in addition to any other discipline imposed. Kiesilng  Assistant General  Lo Nagias Zidan Bisayed Abdel A}, M.D., Cove Number 2010-06050  4304  SAFAA ABDELAL PAGE  11/121 STATE OF FLORIDA  DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, PETITIONER, Ve CASE NO. 2010-08050 NAGLAA ZIDAN ELSAYED ABDEL AL, M.D., RESPONDENT.  DMINI TIVE COMPLAINT  Petitioner, Department of Health, by and through its undersigned counsel, files this Administrative Complaint before the Board of Medicine against Respondent, NAGLAA ZIDAN ELSAYED ABDEL AL, M.D., and in support thereof alleges:  1. Petitioner is the state department charged with regulating the practice of Medicine pursuant to Section 20.43, Florida Statutes; Chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed physician within the State of Florida, having been issued license  number ME100169.  4289 3. | Respondent’s address of record is 13278 Roxboro Road, Windemere, Florida 34786.  4. The Arizona Medical Board (Arizona Board) is the licensing authority regulating the practice of medicine in the State of Arizona.  5. On or about April 14, 2010, the Arizona Board took action against Respondent's license and entered an Interim Consent Agreement and Order (Jn the Matter of Naglaa Z. Abdel-Al, M.D.; Holder of License Number 34898, for the Practice of Allopathic Medicine in the State of Arizona) against the Respondent. |  6. The Interim Consent Agreement and Order entered by the Arizona Board imposed the following conditions on the Respondent's Arizona license: Respondent shall not practice clinical medicine or any medicine involving direct patient care, and is prohibited from prescribing any form of treatment including prescription medications, until Respondent  - applies to the Board and receives permission to do so.  7. Respondent failed to notify the Florida Board of Medicine in  writing within thirty (30) days of the action taken against the Respondent's —  license by the Arizona Board on or about April 14, 2010.  4290 COUNT ONE  8. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference the allegations contained in paragraphs one (1) through six (6) as if fully set forth herein. |  9. Section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes (2009), sets forth grounds for disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine and provides that having a license or the authority to practice medicine revoked, suspended, or otherwise acted against, including the denial of licensure, by the licensing authority of another state constitutes grounds for discipline. The  | licensing authority’s acceptance of a physician's relinquishment of license,  , stipulation, consent order, or other settlement, offered in response to or in  anticipation of the filing of an administrative action against the physician's license, shall be construed as action against the physician's license.  10. The Arizona Board acted against the Respondent's medical license on or about April 14, 2010, by entering the above referenced Interim Consent Agreement and Order.  11. Based on the foregoing facts and drcumstances, the Respondent violated Section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes (2009), by  having the Respondent's medical license or the authority to practice  4291_ medicine revoked, suspended, or otherwise acted against, including the denial of licensure, by the licensing authority of another state. COUNT TWO | 12. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference the allegations contained in paragraphs one (1) through seven (7) as if fully set forth herein.  13. Section 458.331(1)(kk), Florida Statutes (2009) provides that failing to report to the Board, in writing within thirty (30) days, if action, as defined in Section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes, has been taken against one’s license to practice as a physician in another state, territory or country, constitutes grounds for discipline by the Florida Board of Medicine.  14. Respondent failed to report the actions taken against Respondent's license by the Arizona Board on or about April 14, 2010, to the Florida Board of Medicine in writing within thirty (30) days.  15. Based on the foregoing, Respondent violated Section 458.331(1)(kk), Florida Statutes (2009), by failing to report to the Florida Board of Medicine in writing, within thirty (30) days of the action being taken against Respondent's license on or about April 14, 2010, by the  Arizona Board.  4292 WHEREFORE, Petitioner respectfully requests the Board of Medicine enter an order imposing one or more of the following penalties: permanent revocation or suspension of Respondent’s license, restriction of practice, imposition of an administrative fine, issuance of a reprimand, placement of the Respondent on probation, corrective action, refund of fees billed or collected, remedial education and/or any other relief that the Board deems  appropriate. OTICE REGARDING MENT OF Ss  Respondent is placed on notice that Petitioner has incurred costs related to the investigation and prosecution of this matter. Pursuant to Section 456.072(4), Florida Statutes, the Board shall assess costs related to the investigation and prosecution of a disciplinary matter, which may include attorney hours and costs, on the Respondent in addition te any other discipline imposed.  4294 Accordingly, the parties shall adhere to and abide by all the terms and conditions of the Settlement Agreement as clarified above.  At the meeting, and based upon the testimony and documentation provided by the Professionals Resource Network (PRN), the Board determined that Respondent has demonstrated the ability to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety and therefore reinstated the Respondent's license to practice medicine in the State of Florida. Stipulated Disposition in this matter,  Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of medicine pursuant to Section 20.43, Florida Statutes, and Chapter 456, Florida Statutes, and Chapter 458, Plorida Statutes. :  1. Atal times material hereto, Respondent was a licensed physician in the State of Florida having been issued license number ME 100169.  2. The Department charged Respondent with an Administrative  Complaint that was filed and properly served upan Respondent with violations of  Nagisa Ziden Blayed Abdel Al, M.D, Case Number 2010-02050,  4295 86/14/2811 16:38 4076542256  Chapter 458, Florida Statutes, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto. AMBATI, M.D., |  Respondent. ee  ADMINISTRATIVE COMPLAINT  Petitioner Department of Health files this Administrative Complaint before the Board of Medicine against Respondent Balamurali K. Ambati, M.D., and in support thereof alleges:  1. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of Medicine pursuant to Section 20.43, Florida Statutes; Chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed medical doctor within the state of Florida, having been issued license number ME 128144.  3. Respondent's address of record is 2050 Goodpasture Loop,  Unit 95, Eugene, OR 97401. 4. Respondent is also licensed to practice medicine in the state of Idaho by the Idaho Medical Board (Idaho Board), the licensing authority regulating the practice of medicine in Idaho.  5. On or about January 8, 2018, the Idaho Board took action against Respondent's license in case number 2017-9119 via a Stipulation of Licensure and Order (Stipulation) for Respondent's failure to correctly answer three questions correctly on his application for license renewal.  6. The Stipulation required Respondent to pay a $1,500 fine ($500 for each false statement on his license application, required Respondent to pay investigative costs and attorney fees, and required Respondent to complete an ethics course.  7. | The January 8, 2018, Stipulation of the Idaho Board constitutes action against Respondent's medical license.  8. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through seven (7), as if fully set forth herein,  9. Section 458. 331(1)(b), Florida Statutes (2018), provides that . having a license or the authority to practice medicine revoked, suspended, or otherwise acted against, including the denial of licensure, by the  licensing authority of any jurisdiction constitutes grounds for disciplinary  action by the Board of Medicine.  DOH v. Balamurall K. Ambati, M.D.; Case Number 2018-00316 2 10. The Idaho Board acted against Respondent's Idaho medical license by entering the above referenced Stipulation on or about January 8, 2018.  11. Based on the foregoing, Respondent violated Section 458.331(1)(b), Florida Statutes (2018), by having his medical license acted against by the medical licensing authority of another jurisdiction. WHEREFORE, the Petitioner respectfully requests that the Board of Medicine enter an order imposing one or more of the following penalties: permanent revocation or suspension of Respondent's license, restriction of practice, administrative fine, issuance of a reprimand, placement of the Respondent on probation, corrective action, refund of fees billed or. collected, remedial education and/or any other relief that the Board deems  appropriate. CASE NO. 2020-30474  ERIC RAUL VALLADARES, M.D.,  RESPONDENT. /  ADMINISTRATIVE COMPLAINT  Petitioner Department of Health hereby files this Administrative Complaint before the Board of Medicine against Respondent Eric Raul Valladares, M.D., and alleges:  1. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of medicine pursuant to section 20.43, Florida Statutes; chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed physician within the state of Florida, having been issued license number ME 91049.  3. Respondent's address of record is P.O. Box 451050, Miami, FL 33245.  4. At all times materia! to this Complaint, Respondent was the designated physician at Jolie Plastic Surgery, Inc., located at 8506 SW 8" Street, Suite 8512, Miami, FL 33144.  5. On or about June 23, 2021, pursuant to a Department investigation, an office surgery inspection was conducted at Jolie Plastic Surgery by Inspector K.E. and  Inspector S.C. 6, The Department inspectors requested access to several documents and the surgical suite to complete their inspection.  7. After five hours, Inspectors K.E. and S.C. left Jolie Plastic Surgery due to the facility staff’s refusal to provide access to requested documents, refusal to provide access to the office’s surgical suite, and the staff’s increasing hostility and aggression towards the inspectors.  8, After the limited inspection of the facility, the inspectors reported the following deficiencies, in violation of the following Board Rules:  a. Rule 64B8-9.0091(1)(c), F.A.C., by failing to notify the Department of changes to the registration information including Dr. Z.P. no longer practicing at the facility and Dr. A.H. practicing at the facility; and/or  b. Rule 64B8-9,009(4){b)2, F.A.C., by permitting physicians to perform procedures at the facility without the required transfer agreements and/or staff privileges at a licensed hospital within reasonable proximity.  COUNT I — SECTION 458.331(1)(mn)  9. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through eight (8), as if fully set forth herein.  10. Section 458.331(1)(nn), Florida Statutes (2020), provides that violating any provision of this chapter or chapter 456, or any rules adopted pursuant thereto is grounds for disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine.  11. Section 458.328(1)(g), Florida Statutes (2020), provides that the  Department may impose any penalty set forth in section 456.072(2), against the  DOH v, Eric Rau! Valladares, M.D. Case Number 2020-30474 2 of 8  designated physician for failure of the office to operate in compliance with the office health and safety requirements of this section and rules adopted hereunder.  12. The Board of Medicine has established Requirements for Physician Office Surgery Registration; Inspection or Accreditation in Rule 64B8-9.0091, F.A.C.  13. The Board’s rule required each physician practicing at a registered office to notify the Board in writing within 10 calendar days after beginning or ending his or her practice at a registered office,  14. | Respondent failed to comply with the requirements for physician office surgery registration, inspection, or accreditation, as established by Rule 64B8-9.0091, F.A.C., by failing to notify the Department of changes to the registration information.  15. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated section 458.331(1)(nn), Florida Statutes (2020), by violating Rule 64B8-9.0091, FA.C.  COUNT II — SECTION 458.331(1)(nn)  16. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through eight (8), as if fully set forth herein.  17. Section 458.331(1)(nn), Florida Statutes (2020), provides that violating any provision of this chapter or chapter 456, or any rules adopted pursuant thereto is grounds for disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine.  18. Section 458.328(1)(g), Florida Statutes (2020), provides that the Department may impose any penalty set forth in s. 456.072(2) against the designated physician for failure of the office to operate in compliance with the office health and safety  requirements of this section and rules adopted hereunder.  DOH v. Eric Raul Valladares, M.D. Case Number 2020-30474 30f 8 19. The Board of Medicine has set a minimum standard of care for office surgeries in Rule 64B8-9.009, F.A.C.  20. The Board’s rule required that the physician, or the facility where the procedure is being performed, must have a transfer agreement with a licensed hospital within reasonable proximity if the physician performing the procedure does not have staff privileges to perform the same procedure as that being performed in the out-patient setting at a licensed hospital within reasonable proximity.  21. Respondent failed to meet the minimum standard of care for office surgeries, as required by Rule 64B8-9.009(4)(b)(2), FA.C., by permitting physicians to perform procedures at the facility without the required transfer agreements and/or staff privileges at a licensed hospital within reasonable proximity.  22. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated section 458.331(1)(nn), Florida Statutes (2020), by violating Rule 64B8-9.009, F.A.C.  COUNT ITI — SECTION 458.331(1)(hh)  23. Petitioner re-alleges and incorporates by reference paragraphs one (1) through seven (7), as if fully set forth herein.  24. Section 458.331(1)(hh), Florida Statutes (2020), provides that improperly interfering with an investigation or with any disciplinary proceeding is grounds for disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine.  25. Respondent improperly interfered with an investigation when employees of the facility of which he is the designated physician refused to allow Department inspectors  to inspect documents and the facility.  DOH vy, Eric Raul Valladares, M.D. Case Number 2020-30474 40f8 26. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated section 458.331(1)(hh), Florida Statutes (2020).  WHEREFORE, Petitioner respectfully requests that the Board of Medicine enter an order imposing one or more of the following penalties: permanent revocation or suspension of Respondent's license, restriction of practice, imposition of an administrative fine, issuance of a reprimand, placement of Respondent on probation, corrective action, refund of fees billed or collected, remedial education and/or any other relief that the  Board deems appropriate. DOH v. Anna Laura Maloy, M.D. DOH Case No. 2013-00659 4, Respondent is board certified in Emergency Medicine by the American Board of Emergency Medicine.  5. On February 15, 2011, Patient BD, a 49 year-old female, presented to St. Lucie Emergency Department (Hospital ED) with shortness of breath and a cough. Another doctor diagnosed BD with pneumonia, administered nebulizer treatments, and released her home with oral antibiotics.  6. On February 22, 2011, BD presented to Physicians Immediate Care, an emergency walk in clinic (Clinic). Her complaint was right side pain/tightness and acute shortness of breath. Her vital signs were BP 160/96; P: 121; R: 16; T 98.6; O2 saturation: 87%.  7. The Clinic doctor made the following entries in his records  we - : under. the heading of treatment: “With pt. oxygen status and SOB, cP it is  es ; posable a PE [pulmonary embolism] could have been thrown. Needs to go  | to ER.” The Clinic doctor ordered that BD be continuously monitored by clinic staff until EMS arrived to transport her to the Emergency Department.  8. The St. Lucie County Fire District Rescue Unit responded to the Clinic and transported BD to the Hospital ED, which took approximately 20  minutes. The EMS documentation contains the following entries: “Noted  DOH v. Anna Laura Maloy, M.D. 2 DOH Case No. 2013-00659  respiratory wheezing in all fields. When patient was removed from the 02, the pts 02 sat dropped down to 86. r/o [Rule out] pulmonary embolism. ER contacted without questions or orders. Written and verbal report given to ER staff.” The documentation contained the following vital signs: “Pulse 102; Resp: 22; Respiratory effort; Labored; SaO2: 86% (on room air).”  9. The triage records at the Hospital ED document the vital signs as BP: 159/90; HR: 98; T 98.8; SpO2%: 88.  10. Respondent was the ED doctor assigned to evaluate and treat BD on February 22, 2011. In performing her evaluation, she used a “Shortness of Breath” chief complaint-driven template from Xpress Technologies.  11. Respondent relied on the vital signs taken at triage and  AB recorded no. vital signs as Part of her physical examination of BD. The  my history and physical information that Respondent entered consisted of the . following: “48y [female] with cough, fever, flu x 1-2 weeks. Treated w/ Z- pak, initially, better, now symptoms have returned, cough productive, scant sputum... .” She notes that BD “can’t get enough air.”  12. Respondent ordered a portable chest x-ray which was interpreted as “No acute cardiac or pulmonary pathology. The apparent  lingular infiltrate seen on 02/15/11 has resolved.” Respondent also  DOH v. Anna Laura Maloy, M.D. 3 DOH Case No. 2013-00659  ordered blood work, one of which was significant for a potassium level of 2.8. Achest x-ray is non-diagnostic for a pulmonary embolism.  13. The Respondent treated BD with two IV antibiotics and oral potassium chloride to treat Respondent’s diagnosis of “Cough; Hypokalemia; Bronchitis.” Respondent also prescribed potassium chloride tablets and antibiotic tablets. She then discharged BD.  14. On March 3, 2011, BD died from a saddle pulmonary embolism that was focally adherent, meaning the embolus itself was not an acute process.  15. The “Shortness of Breath” chief complaint-driven template from Xpress Technologies that Respondent used to evaluate BD on February 22, 2011, contained a section for “Medical Decision Making” for Differential Diagnostic Considerations. In that section, one differential diagnosis , consideration listed is pulmonary embolus. That is the same differential | diagnosis that BD was sent to the ER with, from the Clinic and by EMS, and no consideration for pulmonary embolism is documented as being entertained.  16. Based on BD's heart rate, labored breathing and low O2 saturation, and in light of the referral from the Clinic to rule out pulmonary  embolism, the standard of care required Respondent to evaluate BD for  DOH v. Anna Laura Maloy, M.D. 4 DOH Case No. 2013-00659 pulmonary embolism, test for embolism by performing a D-dimer test, and  7 ; i document the findings of the examination and the test.  7 17. A D-dimer tests for a fibrin degradation product (or FDP), a small protein fragment present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis. While a negative result practically rules out thrombosis, a positive result can indicate thrombosis, but does not rule out other potential causes.  18. By failing to integrate the history and physical findings, and further failing to perform any test(s) that could exclude the possibility of pulmonary embolism, Respondent practiced below the standard of care.  19. If Respondent considered the possibility of pulmonary  . embolism, she failed to document ruling out that diagnosis in the section  ae 2 oft the template that was reserved for. that purpose.  o 20. _ Respondent did not adequately assess BD’s complaints and  ee symptoms an dno complete and proper history and physical examination  was documented.  21. Respondent failed to document acknowledgment of the records from the Clinic and EMS that the reason for transfer was to rule out pulmonary embolism.  DOH v. Anna Laura Maloy, M.D. 5 DOH Case No. 2013-00659 22. Respondent's diagnosis of BD's condition was_ inappropriate, inadequate, inaccurate, and untimely. If Respondent had simply read the ‘Clinic referral documents and attempted to rule out pulmonary embolism by performing the D-dimer test, she would have known whether she needed to proceed with different tests toward a different diagnosis.  23. Respondent’s medical records do not justify the course of treatment. Specifically, the records do not justify the use of antibiotics or the failure to perform the D-dimer test. They do not document the possible differential diagnosis of pulmonary embolism or a complete history or physical examination.  COUNT ONE  24. Petitioner realleges and incorporates paragraphs one (1)  ok throu ough twenty-three (23) as if fully set forth: herein.  ee 25, ‘Section 458. 331(1)(t)L., Florida Statutes (2010), subjects a  ne doctor to discipline by the Board of Medicine for committing medical malpractice as defined in Section 456.50. Section 456.50, Florida Statutes (2010), defines medical malpractice as the failure to practice medicine in accordance with the level of care, skill, and treatment  recognized in general law related to health care licensure. The level of care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law  wie related to health care licensure means the standard of care specified in  - Section 766.102. The prevailing professional standard of care for a given health care provider shall be that level of care, skill, and treatment which, in light of all relevant surrounding circumstances, is recognized as acceptable and appropriate by reasonably prudent similar health care providers... .”  27. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of medicine pursuant to section 20.43, Florida Statutes; chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2.  Atall times material to this complaint, Respondent was a licensed physician within the state of Florida, having been issued license number ME  127962. 3. Respondent's address of record is 7258 Southeast 2nd Street, Ocala, Florida 34480.  4.  Analternate address for Respondent is 3206-3208 Hillsdale Lane, Kissimmee, Florida 34731.  5. On or about February 27, 2020, the Agency for Health Care Administration terminated Respondent's participation in the state Medicaid program.  6. Respondent has not had his participation in the state Medicaid program reinstated by the Agency for Health Care Administration.  7. Respondent was terminated from participation in the state Medicaid program on or about February 27, 2020.  9. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated section 456.072(1)(kk), Florida Statutes (2019). Petitioner is the state department charged with regulating the practice of medicine pursuant to Section 20.43, Florida Statutes; Chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed medical doctor within the state of Florida, having been issued license number ME 41360.  -3,. Respondent's address of record is 1361 13 Avenue South, Suite 140, Jacksonville Beach, Florida 32250.  4. Respondent is board certified in general surgery.  1578  5. Patient M.Y. (MY), a then-69 year-old female, was admitted through the emergency room to Baptist Medical Center-Beaches on July 16, 2007, with an admitting diagnosis of obstructive jaundice, cholecystitis with cholelithlasis and choledocholithiasis, diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension and psoriasis. Respondent was the attending physician.  6. At the time’of admission, MY denied any abdominal pain. She also did not report abdominal pain to any of the consulting physicians.  7. A pre-operative CT scan and an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) were performed. An ERCP is a procedure in which a dye is injected into the bile and pancreatic ducts using a flexible, video endoscope. Then x-rays are taken to outline the bile ducts and pancreas.  | 8. The CT scan and ERCP indicated a mass in the proximal common hepatic duct, which would be consistent with a cholangiocarcinoma causing obstruction. In addition, there was a small stone seen In the distal common bile duct, which was removed by the ERCP along with a sphincterotomy, An intraductal drain was placed beyond the area of potential obstruction such that MY had a source of  internal drainage.  DOH v. Abbas Shariat, M.D.; 2008-08936  1579  - 9, Definitive diagnosis could have been made by follow-up CT scan-guided biopsies. There was no need for urgent cholecystectomy.  10. At the time Respondent was performing the laparoscopic cholecystectomy, he observed multiple small plaques or nodules on the surface of the liver. He elected not to biopsy those to determine if they represented metastatic disease. tad he done so, he could had closed and completed the surgery ‘without performing the unnecessary cholecystectomy.  11. Patient MY suffered an apparent intra-operative injury which Respondent did not recognize. When MY became hypotensive, Respondent should have immediately shifted to an open procedure to determine the source of the bleeding and corrected it. Failing to do so made all the other measures taken post-operatively to resuscitate MY and perform an arteriogram heroic, but doomed.  12. Respondent practiced below the standard of care when he went forward with an unwarranted “urgent” cholecystectomy when it was | unnecessary.  13. Section 458.331(1)(t)1, Florida Statutes (2007), subjects a doctor to discipline for committing medical malpractice as defined in Section 456.50. Section 456.50, Florida Statutes (2007), defines medical  DOH v. Abbas Shariat, M.0.; 2008-08936 3  1580  malpractice as the failure to practice medicine in accordance with the level of care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law related to health care licensure.  14. Level of care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law related to health care licensure means the standard of care specified in Section 766.102. Section 766.102(1), Florida Statutes (2007), defines the standard of care to mean“... : The prevailing professional standard of care for a given health care provider shall be that level of care, skill, and treatment which, in light of all relevant surrounding circumstances, Is recognized as acceptable and appropriate by reasonably prudent similar health care providers. .. .”  15. Respondent failed to meet the prevailing standard of care in one or more of the following ways:  a. By performing an unwarranted “urgent” cholecystectomy when  it was unnecessary;  b. By failing to convert to an open procedure to determine the  source of the bleeding and correct it;  c.. By falling to biopsy liver plaques or nodules and then terminate  the procedure once he had begun performing it.  DOH v. Abbas Shariat, M.D.; 2008-08936  1581 16. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated Section 458.331(1)(t)1, Florida Statutes (2007), by committing medical malpractice.  WHEREFORE, Petitioner respectfully requests that the Board of Medicine enter an order imposing one or more of the following penalties: permanent revocation or suspension of Respondent's license, restriction of practice, Imposition of an administrative fine, issuance of a reprimand, placement of Respondent on probation, corrective action, refund of fees  billed or collected, remedial education and/or any other relief that the  Board deems appropriate. DRAPER, M.D.,  Respondent.  ee | ADMINISTRATIVE COMPLAINT  Petitioner Department of Health files this Administrative Complaint before the Board of Medicine against Respondent Victoria F. Draper, M.D., and states:  1. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of medicine, pursuant to Chapters 20, 456, and 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this matter, Respondent was licensed to practice as a physician in the State of Florida. Respondent's license number is ME 80420. ,  3. | Respondent's address of record is 1518 Adriatic Drive, Ocoee,  Florida 34761.  DOH v. Victoria Draper, MD Case No. 2011-19775  to consider modalities of treatment other than just the use of controlled substances.  28. The medical records created by Respondent for Patient DT do not document justification for the types and amounts of medications prescribed by Respondent. The medical records do not contain a treatment plan that identified treatment objectives. The medical records do not document any significant abnormal examinations, findings, or functional changes in the patient that would justify the treatment prescribed by Respondent.  COUNT ONE  29. Petitioner realleges and incorporates paragraphs 1 through 28 as if fully set forth herein.  30. Section 458.331(1)(t)1, Florida Statutes (2010-2011), subjects a physician to discipline for committing medical malpractice as defined in Section 456.50, Florida Statutes (2010-2011). Medical malpractice is defined by Section 456.50(1)(g), Florida Statutes (2010-2011), as the failure to practice medicine in accordance with the level of care, skill, and  treatment recognized in general law related to health care licensure.  10  31. Level of care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law related to health care licensure means the standard of care that is specified in Section 766.102(1), Florida Statutes (2010-2011), which states as follows:  The prevailing professional standard of care for a given health  care provider shall be that level of care, skill, and treatment  which, in light of all relevant surrounding circumstances, is  recognized as acceptable and appropriate by reasonably prudent similar health care providers...  32. Respondent failed to meet the prevailing professional standard of care in one or more of the following manners:  a. By prescribing large quantities of controlled substances over an extended period of time without adequate medical justification;  b. By failing to refer Patient DT for further evaluation or consultation with other appropriate medical providers;  c. By failing to employ other modalities for the treatment of pain in connection with Patient DT;  d. ‘By failing to properly monitor Patient DT regarding his  unexplained drug test results; and  11 e. By failing to comply with the standards for prescribing controlled substances for pain management as set out in Rule 64B8- 9.013, Florida Administrative Code.  33. Based on the foregoing, Respondent violated Section 458.331(1)(t)1, Florida Statutes (2010-2011).  COUNT TWO  34. Petitioner realleges and incorporates by reference the allegation in paragraphs 1 through and 28.  35. Section 458.331(1)(m), Florida Statutes (2010-2011), subjects a licensee to discipline for failing to keep legible, as defined by department rule in consultation with the board, medical records that justify the course of treatment of the patient, including, but not limited to, patient histories; examination results; test results; records of drugs prescribed, dispensed, or administered; and reports of consultations and hospitalizations.  36. Respondent failed to keep legible medical records that justified Respondent's course of treatment of Patient DT, specifically, by failing to document one or more of the following:  a. By failing to document the performance of a complete  medical history and physical examination;  12. b. By failing to document the creation of a written treatment plan with objectives to determine the success of the treatment of the patient;  c. — By failing to document any history related to drug abuse or dependence and by failing to document any discussion or monitoring of his medication levels given the unexplained drug screen results;  d. By failing to document the referral of Patient DT for additional evaluations and consultations to determine the etiology of his continued pain; and  e. By failing to keep legible medical records that justify the course of treatment solely with large quantities of controlled substances and no documentation of consideration of alternative treatment modalities for DM.  37. Based on the foregoing, Respondent violated Section 458.331(1)(m), Florida Statutes (2010-2011).  Facts specific to Patient DQ 38. On April 19, 2011, Patient DQ presented to Dr. KM at the  Casselberry Relief Center (Clinic) in Casselberry, Florida, with complaints of  13 we  back pain. Records indicate that Patient DQ disclosed a medication history consisting of an existing prescription for 120 tablets of hydrocodone 10 mg. Patient DQ presented with a MRI performed in 2008 that showed a small L5-S1 disc protrusion. | |  39. A urine drug screen was performed on this visit and was positive for morphine/opiates and oxycodone, even though the patient reported previous prescriptions for only hydrocodone. Despite this, Dr. KM, a doctor at the clinic, prescribed Patient DQ 90 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg, Lortab, twice a day, Naprosyn, and Ambien.  40. On May 17, 2011, Patient DQ presented to Dr. KM for a follow- up appointment. An examination was not performed and Patient DQ’s prescriptions were refilled.  41. On June 20, 2011, although no appointment was documented, Dr. KM prescribed 90 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg, Lortab, twice a day, Naprosyn, and Ambien to Patient DQ.  42. On July 8, 2011, Patient DQ presented to the Clinic and was seen by Respondent. Respondent noted that the patient had gone through 30 days of medication in 16 days. The patient indicated that he was  interested in detoxification. In spite of this, Respondent increased the  14 patient's oxycodone prescription from 90 tablets to 120 tablets 30 mg. Respondent eliminated the patient’s prescription for Lortab and added a prescription for Valium.  43. Respondent’s medical records contain no justification for increasing Respondent's oxycodone, the addition of Valium and the discontinuance of Naproxen for Patient DQ.  44. Respondent referred Patient DQ for an MRI. The MRI was performed and showed a small L5-S1 disk compression with no neural compression.  45. On August 8, September 6, and October 4, 2011, Patient DQ presented to Respondent for follow-up appointments. On September 6, 2011, Respondent increased Patient DQ’s prescription from 120 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg to 150 tablets, plus 30 tablets of Valium 10 mag, in spite of previous unexplained drug screen results.  46. In November of 2011, Patient DQ was referred to an addictionologist. The addictionologist reported that the patient was not addicted and safe to treat.  47. Ata follow-up appointment on November 21, 2011, Patient DQ  submitted to a multi-drug urine screen, which was positive for Opiates and  15 oxycodone but negative for benzodiazepine despite the fact the patient was prescribed Valium.  48. Patient DQ’s initial treatment plan included physical therapy, massage and chiropractic treatment. However, after Respondent started treating the patient, Respondent did not follow-up to determine if the patient had obtained any of the above-listed alternative treatments and if so, the effect of the treatment. Respondent did not document that she discussed or offered any other treatment modalities other than prescribed controlled substances. In addition, there is no indication that Respondent considered the patient's discordant drug screens in relation to the continued prescription of controlled substances.  49. The prevailing professional standard for the use of controlled substances for the treatment of pain required Respondent to create a written treatment plan that stated objectives for determining the success of treatment, to consider alternative modalities of treatment.  50. The prevailing professional standard of care required Respondent to alter her prescribing practices or document her reason for not altering her prescribing practices, given the discrepancies between  Patient DQ’s drug screens and prescribed medication.  16 51. The prevailing professional standard of care required Respondent to refer the patient for further evaluation or consultation for the determination of the etiology of the patient’s pain.  52. The medical records created by Respondent for Patient DQ do not document a justification for the types and amounts of medications prescribed by Respondent. In addition, Respondent failed to document a treatment plan that identified treatment objectives and failed to document any significant abnormal examinations findings or functional changes in the patient that would justify the treatment. (b) Treatment Plan. The written treatment plan shall state objectives that will be used to determine treatment success, such as pain relief and improved physical and psychosocial function, and shall indicate if any further diagnostic evaluations or other treatments are planned. After treatment begins, the physician shall adjust drug therapy, if necessary, to the individual medical needs of each patient. Other treatment modalities or a rehabilitation program may be necessary depending on the etiology of the pain and the extent to which the pain is associated with physical and psychosocial impairment.  (c) Informed Consent and Agreement for Treatment. The physician shall discuss the risks and benefits of the use of controlled substances with the patient, persons designated by the patient, or with the patient’s surrogate or guardian if the patient is incompetent. The patient shall receive prescriptions from one physician and one pharmacy where possible. If the patient is determined to be at high risk for medication abuse or have a history of substance abuse, the physician shall employ the use of a written agreement between physician and patient outlining patient responsibilities, including, but not limited to:  1. Urine/serum medication levels screening when requested;  2. Number and frequency of all prescription refills; and  3. Reasons for which drug therapy may be discontinued (i.e., violation of agreement).  (d) Periodic Review. Based on the individual circumstances of the patient, the physician shall review the course of treatment and any new information about the etiology of the pain. Continuation or modification of therapy shall depend on the physician’s evaluation of the patient's progress. If treatment goals are not being achieved, despite medication adjustments, the physician shall reevaluate the appropriateness of continued treatment. The physician shall monitor patient compliance in medication usage and related treatment plans.  (e) Consultation. The physician shail be willing to refer the patient as necessary for additional evaluation and treatment in order to achieve  treatment objectives. Special attention must be given to those pain  patients who are at risk for misusing their medications and those whose living arrangements pose a risk for medication misuse or diversion. The management of pain in patients with a history of substance abuse or with a comorbid psychiatric disorder requires extra care, monitoring, and documentation, and may require consultation with or referral to an expert in the management of such patients.  (f) Medical Records. The physician is required to keep accurate and complete records to include, but not be limited to:  1. The complete medical history and a physical examination, including history of drug abuse or dependence, as appropriate;  2. Diagnostic, therapeutic, and laboratory results;  3. Evaluations and consultations;  4. Treatment objectives;  5. Tiscussion of risks and benefits;  6. Treatments;  7. Medications (including date, type, dosage, and quantity  prescribed);  8. Instructions and agreements;  9. Drug testing results; and  10. Periodic reviews. Records must remain current, maintained  in an accessible manner, readily available for review, and must  be in full compliance with Rule 64B8-9.003, F.A.C, and Section  458.331(1)(m), F.S. While practicing at the Clinics, Respondent regularly prescribed  oxycodone, hydrocodone, Xanax and Valium to patients.  8. | Oxycodone, an opioid, is commonly prescribed to treat pain. According to Section 893.03(2), Florida Statutes (2010-2011), oxycodone is a Schedule If controlled substance.  9. Hydrocodone (brand name Lortab, Vicodin, Lorcet), an opioid analgesic that contains acetaminophen, is commonly prescribed to treat pain. According to Section 893.03(3), Florida Statutes (2010-2011), hydrocodone is a Schedule III controlled substance.  10. Valium (brand name for diazepam, benzodiazepine) is prescribed to treat anxiety. According to Section 893.03(4), Florida Statutes (2010-2011), diazepam is a Schedule IV controlled substance.  11. Xanax (brand name of alprazolam, a benzodiazepine) is prescribed to treat anxiety. According to Section 893.03(4), Florida Statutes (2010-2011), alprazolam is a Schedule IV controlled substance.  , 12. Ambien (brand name for zolpidem) is prescribed to treat insomnia. According to Title 21, Section 1308.14, Code of Federal Regulations, zolpidem is a Schedule IV drug and subject to abuse.  Facts Specific to Patient DT 13. On February 9, 2011, Patient DT presented to the Lake Mary  Clinic with a history of back and knee pain related to an ACL injury. Patient  DT's medical records indicate he reported taking 150 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg and 60 tablets of oxycodone 15 mg per month. Dr. KM examined the patient and increased DT’s prescription to 180 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg, 90 tablets of oxycodone 15 mg, and added Xanax, 30 tablets of Flexeril, a muscle relaxant, and Mobic, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug, (NSAID) used to treat pain, swelling and stiffness.  14. Respondent's medical records for Patient DL’s February 9, 2011, visit contain no justification for either the increase in oxycodone or the addition of a prescription for Xanax.  15. On March 10, 2011, Patient DT presented to the Clinic for a follow-up appointment. Dr. B-C prescribed 112 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg, 56 tablets of oxycodone 15 mg, 28 tablets of Xanax 2 mg and 28 tablets of Mobic 15 mg. In addition, Dr. B-C prescribed massage therapy and chiropractic. .  16. On April 7, 2011, Patient DT presented for a follow-up appointment and was seen for the first time by Respondent. Respondent continued the patient’s prescription for 180 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg,  discontinued the previous prescription for 15 mg oxycodone tablets, added a prescription for Valium 10 mg, deleted the previously prescribed Xanax and added Flexeril.  17. Respondent’s medical records do not justify the course of treatment of the patient in that Respondent did not document why she discontinued the previously prescribed 15 mg oxycodone tablets, discontinued the Xanax and prescribed Valium.  18. On May 5, June 6 and July 5, 2011, Patient DT presented to Respondent for follow-up appointments. At each appointment, Respondent prescribed 180 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg, 30 tablets of Valium 10 mg and 30 tablets of Flexeril 10 mg.  19. On August 5, 2011, Patient DT presented to Respondent for a follow-up appointment. DT submitted to a multi-drug urine screen that was negative for oxycodone and benzodiazepine, notwithstanding the fact that Respondent had repeatedly prescribed oxycodone and benzodiazepine to the patient. Despite these results, Respondent continued the prescription of 180 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg and 30 tablets of Valium 10 mg.  20. Respondent’s medical records for Patient DT’s follow-up on  August 5, 2011, lack any documentation as to any consideration,  explanation or discussion of the patient’s drug screen results or any alteration of Respondent's prescribing practices.  21. On September 2, 2011, Patient DT presented to Respondent for follow-up. DT submitted to another multi-drug screen, which was positive for oxycodone and opiates but was negative for benzodiazepine. Again, despite a second unexplained drug screen result, Respondent prescribed 180 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg and 30 tablets of Valium 10 mg. The medical records contain no documentation justifying the continuation of prescriptions with unexplained drug screen results. —  22. On November i, 2011, Patient DT presented to Respondent for follow-up. DT submitted to a multi-drug urine screen and tested positive for cocaine, oxycodone and benzodiazepines. Again, despite a third unexplained drug screen result, Respondent continued Patient DT’s prescriptions and failed to document any explanation. Respondent documented the referral of Patient DT to an addictionologist.  23. On November 23, 2011, Patient DT presented to Respondent for a follow-up appointment. Respondent continued the previously prescribed 180 tablets of oxycodone 30 mg and 30 tablets of Valium 10  mg. The medical records contain no documentation regarding the consult with the “addictionologist” or previous discrepancies between drug screen results and prescriptions. ,  24. Patient DT’s medical records indicate that the initial treatment plan created by other physicians for the patient included physical therapy, massage and chiropractic treatment. However, once Respondent took over the care of this patient, the medical records do not document the success or failure of the alternative treatment modalities or whether or not the patient was actually pursuing the alternative treatment modalities.  25. The standards for the use of controlled substances for the treatment of pain required Respondent to create a written treatment plan that stated objectives for determining the success of treatment. :  26. The prevailing professional standard of care required Respondent to take affirmative action to address the discrepancies between Patient DT’s drug screen results and his prescribed medication and to document such action.  27. The prevailing professional standard of care required Respondent to follow-up on the previous referrals for the patient to pursue massage therapy and chiropractic treatment and to consult with an  addictionologist. STIPULATED FACTS  1. At all times material hereto, Respondent was a licensed physician in the State of Florida having been issued license number ME 53442. 2. CASE NO. 2012-13724  DANIEL ROBERT SPURRIER, M.D.,  RESPONDENT.  ee  DMINIS: IV MPLAI  The Petitioner, Department of Health, by and through the undersigned counsel, files this Administrative Complaint (Complaint) before the Board of Medicine (Board) against the Respondent, Daniel Robert Spurrier, M.D., and alleges:  1. The Petitioner is the state department charged with regulating the practice of medicine pursuant to Section 20.43, Florida Statutes; Chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, the Respondent was a licensed physician within the state of Florida, having been Issued license  number ME 64663.  Page 1 of 8  -2993—___—______—  -2999  3. The Respondent's address of record is 1400 US Highway 441 North, Suite 538, The Villages, Florida 32159.  4. The Respondent is board certified by the American Board of Neurological Surgery.  5. On or about November 10, 2010, D.P, a 64 year old man, presented to the Respondent at Lee Memorial Hospital for surgical intervention to address his back and leg pain. |  6. The Respondent had diagnosed the patient with a spondylolithesis and foraminal narrowing at the L4-L5 levels of the spine. The Respondent had treated D.P. for several years.  7. On or about November 10, 2010, preoperatively the Respondent planned to perform laminectomies at the L4 and L5 vertebrae and allograft arthordesis and fixation of the spine at the L4 and L5 vertebrae using screws and rods.  8. During surgery, the Respondent performed _ bilateral laminectomies and foraminotomies the L3 and L4 levels, allograph arthrodesis at the L3-L4 and L4-L5 levels as well as bilateral pedicle screw  fixation at L3, L4¢ and LS.  Page 2 of 8  3000  9. The Respondent did not adequately document why he performed surgery on the L3 vertebra.  10. The Respondent did not adequately document the placement of the hardware in the patient's spine.  it. On or about November 13, 2010, D.P. was discharged from the hospital.  12. On or about November 15, 2010, through on or about November 18, 2010, D.P. had a fever, and saw bloody fluid draining from the operative site and contacted the Respondent's office on one or more occasions.  13. From on or about November 15, 2010, through on or about November 18, 2010, the Respondent was out of town.  14. A reasonably prudent physician would have another physician covering for him or her when he or she unavailable to his or her patients. A reasonably prudent physician would have ensured he or she had coverage to address post-operative care for a patient immediately after surgery.  15. From on or about November 15, 2010, through on or about  November 18, 2010, D.P. contacted the Respondent's office for post-  Page 3 of 8  3001  operative care, however, neither the Respondent nor a covering physician was available to consult with the patient or treat the patient.  16. N n f  18. The Petitioner realleges and incorporates paragraphs 1-17 as if fully set forth in this count.  19. Section 458.331(1)(t), Florida Statutes (2011), provides that a licensee is subject to discipline for committing medical malpractice as defined in Section 456.50, Florida Statutes. Section 456.50(1)(g), Florida Statutes (2011), states medical malpractice means the failure to practice medicine in accordance with the level of care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law related to health care licensure.  20. Level of care, skill, and treatment recognized In general law  related to health care licensure means the standard of care specified in  Page 4 of 8  -3002  Section 766.102. Section 766.102(1), Florida Statutes (2011), defines the standard of care to mean “[t]he prevailing professional standard of care for a given health care provider shall be that level of care, skill, and treatment which, in light of all relevant surrounding circumstances, Is recognized as acceptable and appropriate by reasonably prudent similar health care providers.”  21, The Respondent fell below the standard of care by failing to provide for adequate postoperative coverage for patient D.P.  22. Based on the foregoing, the Respondent has violated Section 458.331(1)(t), Florida Statutes (2011), by committing medical malpractice and is subject to disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine.  ce) ical R  23. Section 458.331(1)(m), Florida Statutes (2011), provides that a licensee is subject to discipline for falling to keep legible, as defined by department rule in consultation with the board, medical records that identify the licensed physician or the physician extender and supervising  Physician by name and professional title who is or are responsible for  Page 5 of 8  rendering, ordering, supervising, or billing for each diagnostic or treatment procedure and that justify the course of treatment of the patient, including, but not limited to, patlent histories’ examination results; test results; records of drugs prescribed, dispensed, or administered; and reports of consultations and hospitalizations.  25. The Respondent failed to not document why he performed surgery on the L3 vertebra and the L3-L4 levels of the vertebrae.  26. The Respondent's medical records did not adequately document where the hardware was placed in the patient's spine.  27. Based on the foregoing, the Respondent has violated Section 458.331(1)(m), Florida Statutes (2011), by committing medical malpractice and is subject to disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating ‘the practice of medicine pursuant to section 20.43, Florida Statutes; Chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 458, Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed physician within the state of Florida, having been issued license number ME 64837..  3. Respondent's address of record is: 20423 State Road 7, Suite F6-  199, Boca Raton, Florida 33498.  4. Respondent is board certified by the American Board of Obstetrics and Gynecology, in the field of obstetrics and gynecology.  5.  Onor about December 11, 2017, Patient K.M., then a thirty-five (35) year old female, presented to Respondent at A Woman’s Center of Hollywood, 3829 West Hollywood Boulevard, Suite C, Hollywood, Florida 33021, for a medical termination of her pregnancy (the correct procedure). -  6. Onor about December 11, 2017, Patient S.H. provided informed consent for the medical termination of her pregnancy.  7. On or about December 11, 2017, Respondent performed a surgical termination of pregnancy procedure on.-Patient K.M. (the wrong procedure), instead of assisting Patient K.M. with a medical termination of her pregnancy. -— -  8. Patient K.M. did-not authorize Respondent to perform a surgical termination of pregnancy procedure on her prior to Respondent's performance of the surgical termination of pregnancy procedure.  9. Section 456.072(1)(bb), Florida Statutes (2017), provides that performing or attempting to perform health care services (including the preparation of the patient) on the wrong patient, a wrong-site procedure, a  wrong procedure, or an unauthorized procedure or a procedure that is  DOH v. Harvey Craig Roth, M.D.; DOH Case No. 2017-23375 . 2 medically unnecessary or otherwise unrelated to the patient’s diagnosis or medical condition is grounds for disciplinary action by the Board of Medicine.  10. .Respondent. performed a wrong. procedure and/or an unauthorized procedure when he performed a surgical termination of pregnancy procedure on Patient K.M., instead of assisting her in a medical termination of her pregnancy. -  11. Based on the foregoing, Respondent violated section 456.072(1)(bb), Florida Statutes (2017), by performing a wrong procedure and/or unauthorized procedure on Patient K.M.,. by performing an unauthorized surgical termination of pregnancy: procedure on Patient K.M. instead of assisting Patient.K.M. with a medical termination of her pregnancy. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was a licensed physician within the State of Florida, having been issued license number  ME 89848.  DOH V. In addition, Respondent has listed the following , address on his Florida practitioner profile: 3000 E. Fletcher Avenue, Suite 205, Tampa, Florida 33613.  4. Respondent is certified by the American Board of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.  5. On or about February 22, 2010, Patient W.C., then a 79-year old female, presented to Florida Medical Clinic Surgery Center for a Cervical Epidural Steroid Injection to be performed by Respondent.  6. W.C.'s pre-operative diagnosis was spinal disc degeneration.  7. Respondent's order sheet indicates that his plan was to perform the injection at the C5-C6 level under fluoroscope guidance, with myelographic dye injection and interpretation. C.W. was under monitored anesthesia care (i.e., asleep) during the procedure.  8. Patient C.W. signed a consent form authorizing Respondent to perform a Cervical Epidural Steroid injection at the C5-C6 level.  9. The pre-operative surgical checklist indicates that, prior to undergoing the surgery, W.C. was able to move all four of her extremities.  OOH V. DE LA TORRE, M.D., Case Number 2010-08186 Page 2 of 7  1618  10. Respondent's post-operative notes indicate that he inserted the  needle at the C5-C6 interlaminar space but was unsuccessful in accessing this space, redirected the needle towards the C4-C5 interlaminar space until loss of resistance was felt, injected preservative-free, non-ionic contrast which was observed to flow along the subarachnoid space, pulled the needle back from the subarachnoid space and re-injected the contrast which was observed to flow along the epidural space, and at the same level injected lidocaine 1%.  11. Respondent improperly proceeded with W.C’s epidural steroid injection procedure after It was apparent that he had made an intraspinal puncture.  12. Respondent improperly injected lidocaine into W.C. after it was apparent that he had made an intraspinal puncture.  13. Subsequent to the Surgery, W.C. was transferred to PACU for Post-operative assessment and began complaining of weakness in all four of her extremities.  14. Respondent was notified of W.C's complaints and, when there was no significant improvement, wrote orders for W.C. to be transferred to University Community Hospital for observation and treatment. Section 458.331(1)(t)1., Florida Statutes (2009), subjects an  Physician to discipline for committing medical malpractice as defined in: Section 456.50. “Medical malpractice” is defined by Section 456.50(1)(g), Florida Statutes (2009), as “the failure to practice medicine in accordance with the level of care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law | related to health care licensure.”  16. Section 456.50(1)(e), Florida Statutes (2009), provides that the “level of care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law related to health care licensure" means the standard of care that is specified in Section 766.102, Florida Statutes, as follows:  The prevailing professional standard of care for a given health  care provider shall be that level of care, skill, and treatment  which, in light of all relevant Surrounding circumstances, is  recognized as acceptable and appropriate by reasonably prudent similar health care providers.  17, Respondent falled to meet the prevailing standard of care in regard to Patient W.C. in one or more of the following ways:  a. By improperly proceeding with W.Cs epidural steroid injection procedure after it was apparent that Respondent had made  an intraspinal puncture; and/or  DOH'V. DE LA TORRE, M.D., Case Number 2010-08186 - Page 4 of 7  1619  b. By improperly giving lidocaine after it was apparent that  Respondent had made an intraspinal puncture.  18. Based on the foregoing, Respondent has violated Section: 458.331(1)(t)1., Florida Statutes (2009), by committing medical malpractice.  WHEREFORE, the Petitioner respectfully requests that the Board of Medicine enter an order imposing one or more of the following penalties: permanent revocation or suspension of Respondent's license, restriction of practice, imposition of an administrative fine, issuance of a reprimand, placement of the Respondent on probation, corrective action, refund of fees billed or collected, remedial education and/or any other relief that the  Board deems appropriate.
