CONCLUSIONS OF LAW  49. Because DOH seeks to impose license discipline, it has the burden to prove its allegations by clear and convincing evidence. See Dep’t of Banking & Fin. v. Osborne Stern & Co., Inc., 670 So. 2d 932 (Fla. 1996); Ferris v. Turlington, 510 So. 2d 292 (Fla. 1987). This “entails both a qualitative and quantitative standard. The evidence must be credible; the memories of the witnesses must be clear and without confusion; and the sum total of the evidence must be of sufficient weight to  convince the trier of fact without hesitancy.” In re Davey,  645 So. 2d 398, 404 (Fla. 1994). See also Slomowitz v. Walker, 429 So. 2d 797, 800 (Fla. 4th DCA 1983). “Although this standard of proof may be met where the evidence is in conflict, . .. it  seems to preclude evidence that is ambiguous.” Westinghouse  Elec. Corp. v. Shuler Bros., Inc., 590 So. 2d 986, 988 (Fla. 1st  DCA 1991).  16 40928  The Charges and Proof  50. Count I of the Amended Administrative Complaint charged the Respondent with violating section 456.072(1) (hh), Florida Statutes (2013), by being terminated from her contract with PRN for failing to comply with the requirements of her contract with PRN, without good cause. DOH proved this charge by clear and convincing evidence. Under her PRN contract, the Respondent was required to provide updated contact information. She also was required to submit quarterly reports from her psychiatrist. She failed to comply with these requirements. The Respondent offered excuses and explanations for her failure to comply, but they did not constitute good cause for non-compliance.  S1. Count II of the Amended Administrative Complaint charged the Respondent with violating section 458.331(1) (x), Florida Statutes (2013).  52. Section 458.331(1) (x) made violating a lawful order of the Board a ground for denial of a license or disciplinary action, as specified in section 456.072(2).  53. Board final orders required the Respondent to: undergo an evaluation by PRN; comply with any recommendations made by PRN; enter into a PRN contract, if recommended; and comply with all terms of the contract.  54. DOH proved by clear and convincing evidence that the  Respondent violated section 458.331(1) (x) by failing to comply  17 40929  with all terms of her PRN contract, in direct violation of Board final orders.  55. Count III of the Amended Administrative Complaint charged the Respondent with violating section 458.331(1)(s), Florida Statutes (2014).  56. Section 458.331(1) (s) provided, in pertinent part:  The following acts constitute grounds for  denial of a license or disciplinary action,  as specified in s. 456.072(2):  (s) Being unable to practice medicine with  reasonable skill and safety to patients by  reason of illness or use of alcohol, drugs,  narcotics, chemicals, or any other type of  material or as a result of any mental or  physical condition. That version of the statute remains in effect, and Count III pertains to the Respondent’s present ability to practice medicine under the 2017 version of the Florida Statutes.  57. DOH proved Count III by clear and convincing evidence. The Respondent does not dispute that she is bipolar type I; that she must remain under psychiatric care; that she must take the medication prescribed for her for that condition; that she is not able to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety without a PRN contract; and that she needs retraining, which is not practical or feasible at this time. She disputed some of the other mental conditions that were diagnosed and the need for drug  and alcohol screening and psychotherapy in her PRN contract. She  is attempting to require PRN to reinstate her previous contract;  18 40930  ignore other subsequent diagnoses of her mental condition as a result of the evaluations by Drs. Sylvester, Wilson, and Gadbois; and eliminate the need for alcohol or drug screening or psychotherapy.  58. The Respondent first contended that those evaluations should not have been performed at all because she was not terminated from her previous PRN contract for non-compliance without good cause. The premise for that contention has been rejected.  59. The Respondent next contended that those evaluations should be ignored because she agreed to them under duress. Clearly, she now regrets agreeing to them and would like to turn back the clock, undo her decisions, and avoid the consequences of those evaluations. But she agreed to them in order to enter a new PRN contract. She may well have felt she had no other good options at the time, but she was not under legal duress, and cannot avoid the consequences of the evaluations on that ground.  60. Finally, the Respondent devoted significant time and energy on independent legal research into the ADA. As a result, she argued that the questions asked by the medical professionals who evaluated her for DOH after 2013 were illegal. Based on that argument, she moved to dismiss the charges; exclude the opinions of Drs. Sylvester, Wilson, and Gadbois; and force the  reinstatement of her previous PRN contract.  19 40931  The Respondent’s ADA Argument Fails  61. A public entity is not required to permit an individual to participate in, or benefit from, the goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages and accommodations of a public accommodation, if that individual poses a direct threat to the  health or safety of others. ACLU of Ind. v. Individual Members  of the Ind. State Bd. of Law Exam’rs, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS  106337, at *18 (S.D. Ind. Sept. 20, 2011) (citing language from  Bodenstab v. Cnty. of Cook, 569 F.3d 651, 658 (7th Cir. 2009).  62. The Florida Legislature recognized, through its enactment of section 458.301, Florida Statutes, that the practice of medicine is potentially dangerous to the public if conducted by unsafe or incompetent practitioners. “It is the legislative intent that physicians who fall below minimum competency or who otherwise present a danger to the public shall be prohibited from practicing in this state.” Id.  63. The Florida Supreme Court has also recognized the  danger an unsafe physician can pose to the public. The Court in  Boedy v. Department of Professional Regulation, 463 So. 2d 215,  217 (Fla. 1985), found:  The right of a properly qualified and licensed individual to practice medicine is a valuable property right which must be protected under the constitution and laws of Florida. State ex rel. Sbordy v. Rowlett, 138 Fla. 330, 190 So. 59 (1939). This right is not absolute, however, but is subject to regulation under the police power of this  20  40932  state. Id. at 62. When a conflict arises between the right of a physician to pursue the medical profession and the right of the sovereignty to protect its citizenry, it follows that the rights of the physician must yield to the power of the state to prescribe reasonable rules and regulations which will protect the people from incompetent and unfit practitioners.  The interest of the sovereignty in regulating physicians is especially great since physicians are in a position of public trust and responsibility. Like other professionals, the physician is constantly interacting with the public. As such, mental fitness and emotional stability are essential traits that a physician must possess in order to competently practice medicine in a manner not injurious to the citizenry. See Florida Board of Bar Examiners Re: Applicant, 443  So. 2d 71 (Fla.1983).  64. A public entity may require an individualized assessment, of a licensee with a disability if the licensee poses  a direct threat to the health and safety of others. Theriault v.  Flynn, 162 F.3d 46, 48-49 (lst Cir. 1998). In doing so, however, the public entity must ensure that it complies with all applicable state and federal laws. 65. The Respondent alleges that the Board failed to meet  its obligations under Title II of the ADA. The First Circuit Court of Appeals case of Theriault v. Flynn succinctly states the Board’s obligations under the ADA:  Federal regulations explicitly forbid public  entities from “administer[ing] a licensing or  certification program in a manner that  subjects qualified individuals with disabilities to discrimination on the basis  21  40933  of disability.” See 28 C.F.R. 35.130(b) (6). In the context of licensing or certification, a person is “qualified” and thus within the protected category if he or she can meet the “essential eligibility requirements” for receiving a license or certification, with accommodation made for the disability. See 42 U.S.C. § 12131(2); 28 C.F.R. pt. 35, app. A, at 472 (1997); Applicants v. Texas State Bd. of Law, 1994 WL 923404, at (W.D. Tex. Oct. 11, 1994).  In determining whether “essential eligibility requirements” are met, a public entity properly may consider whether an applicant with a disability poses a direct threat to the health and safety of others. See  28 C.F.R. pt. 35, app. A, at 472-73 (1997); Id. at § 36.208(c). See also Bragdon v. Abbott, 524 U.S. 624, ----, 118 S. Ct. 2196, 2210, 141 L. Ed. 2d 540 (1998) (involving Title III of the ADA) (noting the need to balance the interests of individuals with disabilities against legitimate concerns for public safety); School Board of Nassau County v. Arline, 480 U.S. 273, 287, 107 S. Ct.  1123, 94 L. Ed. 2d 307 (1987) (involving the Rehabilitation Act) (relied on in Bragdon).  Theriault v. Flynn, 162 F.3d 46, 48-49 (lst Cir. 1998).  66. The determination that a person poses a threat may not be based on generalizations or stereotypes about the effects of a particular disability. Instead, it must be based on an individualized assessment, and reasonable judgment that relies on current medical evidence, or the best available objective evidence, to determine: the nature, duration, and severity of the risk; the probability that the potential injury will actually occur; and whether reasonable modifications of policies,  practices, or procedures will mitigate the risk. ACLU of Ind. v.  22 40934  Individual Members of the Ind. State Bd. of Law Exam’rs, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 106337, at *18-19.  67. In this case, the Board did not act based on generalizations or stereotypes when it required the Respondent to undergo evaluations. Rather, it has acted based on particular and specific allegations of harm to the public in the form of nine malpractice allegations in a short period of time.  68. Participation in and continued compliance with the PRN program is a reasonable accommodation for the Respondent’s mental condition.  69. The PRN requirement was not imposed on the Respondent based on generalizations or stereotypes about the effects of the Respondent’s bipolar disorder. It was related to the nine specific instances of medical malpractice committed by the Respondent between March 2001 and January 2003. The allegations against the Respondent constituted grounds for discipline against the Respondent’s license, with penalties up to and including revocation of her medical license. The Board’s final orders attempted to accommodate the Respondent’s bipolar condition and enable her to maintain her license, while also fulfilling the Board’s obligation to ensure the safety of the public. The Respondent is not safe to practice medicine without a PRN  contract.  23  40935  70. Enrollment in an impaired practitioner treatment program is a reasonable accommodation under the ADA, so long as the practitioner enrolls and progresses satisfactorily in the program and does not constitute a threat to the public. See  ‘Blair v. Bureau of Prof’l & Occupational Affairs, State Bd. of Nursing, 72 A.3d 742, 753 (Pa. Commw. Ct. 2013).  71. The Respondent has the opportunity to demonstrate her fitness to resume the practice of medicine at reasonable intervals. § 458.331(1)(s), Fla. Stat. The Florida Supreme Court in Boedy noted this opportunity as a reason for upholding the state’s police power in ordering mental examinations of physicians. Boedy, 463 So. 2d at 218.  72. The subsequent evaluations in this case are analogous to those required in Theriault v. Flynn, 162 F.3d 46, 49 (1st Cir. 1998). In that case, the Plaintiff, Mr. Theriault, alleged that the New Hampshire Department of Safety violated his rights by requiring him to take a third road test to renew his driver’s license. Id. Mr. Theriault did not dispute that his cerebral palsy limited the use of his hands; however, Mr. Theriault argued that his condition was the same or possibly improved since the previous road test he passed. Id. The court found that the Department of Safety’s “asking [Mr. Theriault] to demonstrate  that he remained qualified to drive was not only permissible but  24  40936  also the state’s obligation in balancing the rights of the disabled.” Id.  73. Likewise, the Respondent does not dispute having a disabling mental condition. Based on that condition, PRN lawfully required the Respondent to be re-evaluated to either demonstrate her current ability to practice medicine safely or to facilitate PRN creating appropriate monitoring terms if the Respondent was not safe to practice. Such subsequent, periodic testing is similar to that approved in Theriault.  74. To support her position, the Respondent cited various cases that discuss questions on licensing applications, including: Clark v. Virginia Bd. of Bar Examiners, 880 F. Supp. 430 (E.D. Va. 1995); and Medical Society of New Jersey v. Jacobs, 1993 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 14294 (D.N.J. Oct. 5, 1993).  75. The cases cited by the Respondent are readily distinguishable in that they address application questions that could rule out applicants prospectively based on generalizations or stereotypes and not based on actual harm or threat of harm. The requirement that the Respondent be evaluated, and her subsequent 2005 contract with PRN, arose from nine malpractice allegations in a short period of time. The Board’s requirement met the obligations outlined by Theriault and was a reasonable  accommodation for the Respondent’s mental illness.  25  PRN evaluation and the Board shall make the determination of whether Respondent is safe to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety. The Board retains jurisdiction in this matter to impose terms and conditions upon reinstatement of Respondent’s license, including, but not limited to, a period of probation with said terms and conditions to be set at the time of reinstatement.  3. Respondent shall be and hereby is REPRIMANDED by the Board.  RULING ON MOTION TO ASSESS COSTS  The Board reviewed the Petitioner’s Motion to Assess Costs and imposes the costs associated with this case in the amount of $71,170.16. Said costs are to be paid within 6 months of reinstatement of Respondent’s license to practice medicine.  (NOTE: SHE RULE 64B8-8.0011, FLORIDA ADMINISTRATIVE CODE. UNLESS OTHERWISE SPECIFIED BY FINAL ORDER, THE RULE SETS FORTH THE REQUIREMENTS FOR PERFORMANCE OF ALL PENALTIES CONTAINED IN THIS FINAL  ORDER. )  DONE AND ORDERED this Ze) day of r  2018.  BOARD OF MEDICINE  Claudia Kemp, J.D., Executive Director  For Jorge J. Lopez, M.D., Chair 40937  76. Even in the case of license applicants, questions from public entities inquiring about diagnoses for serious mental ilinesses, including bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, paranoia, or “any other psychotic disorder,” have been upheld by the courts against Title II scrutiny. Applicants v. Tex. State Bd. of Law Exam’rs, 1994 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 21290 (W.D. Tex. Oct. 11, 1994) (upholding limited inquiry into whether applicant has been diagnosed with or treated for “bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, paranoia, or any other psychotic disorder” within the last ten years); O’Brien v. Va. Bd. of Bar Exam’rs, 1998 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 4344 (E.D. Va. Jan. 23, 1998) (denying preliminary injunction from asking an applicant questions about mental health diagnoses in the last five years).  77. The courts have determined that public entities have a sound basis for crafting temporally broad questions regarding serious mental illnesses because serious mental illnesses tend to recur throughout a person’s lifetime. ACLU of Ind. v. Individual Members of the Ind. State Bd. of Law Examiners, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 106337, at *24.  78. Courts have held that bipolar disorder is a serious mental illness, and due to the unpredictable nature of the 1liness, inquiry into past diagnosis and treatment of bipolar  disorder is necessary to provide the Board with the best  26 40938  information available with which to assess the functional capacity of the individual. Id.  79. The evaluations of the Respondent were lawful under the ADA and met the criteria established by the courts in Theriault and ACLU of Indiana.  The Appropriate Disposition  80. It would be the Respondent’s first preference to avoid the financial and other consequences of participation in PRN by simply having her medical license restricted to prohibit her from patient care. She believes that would enable her to obtain gainful employment with the federal Social Security Administration as a medical reviewer and reduce or eliminate her need to be on disability. Assuming that is the case, the Respondent’s proposal might serve to protect the public from unsafe practice, but it would not be an appropriate outcome. It would be like having a medical license that prohibits the practice of medicine, which is defined as “the diagnosis, treatment, operation, or prescription for any human disease, pain, injury, deformity, or other physical or mental condition.” § 458.305(3), Fla. Stat. (2017).  81. If her first preference is not available, the Respondent would concede that she should not be allowed to practice medicine unless she is under contract with PRN.  However, she would prefer to have her previous PRN contract  27 40939  reinstated. This would eliminate the need for drug and alcohol screening and psychotherapy. It appears that those things may well be unnecessary for the Respondent and that PRN could eliminate them. However, it would not be appropriate based on this evidentiary record to order PRN to do so, or to ignore the Respondent’s more recent evaluations.  82. Florida Administrative Code Rule 64B8-8.001 provides notice of the range of disciplinary penalties that could be imposed for violations of sections 456.072 and 458.331, Florida Statutes. The rule also provides aggravating and mitigating factors to consider should a penalty outside the disciplinary guidelines be recommended. Among those factors is the likelihood that a patient or the public could be exposed to injury or death, and the disciplinary history of the licensee. Fla. Admin. Code R. 64B8-8.001 (3) (a).  83. In 2013 when the violation alleged in Count I occurred, the penalties authorized for a violation of section 456.072(1) (bh) ranged from suspension until licensee demonstrates compliance with all terms of the monitoring or treatment contract, and the ability to practice with reasonable skill and safety, to be followed by a term of probation, and a fine of $1,000 to $2,500, to revocation. Fla. Admin. Code R. 64B8-  8.001(2) (ww) (May 28, 2012).  28  40940  84. In 2013 when the violation alleged in Count II occurred, the penalties authorized for a violation of section 458.331(1) (x) ranged from reprimand and an administrative fine from $5,000.00 to $10,000.00, to revocation or denial, based upon the severity of the offense and the potential for patient harm. Fla. Admin. Code R. 64B8-8.001(2) (x)2. (May 28, 2012).  85. The penalties authorized for the violation of section 458.331(1)(s) alleged in Count III range from probation, to denial or indefinite suspension until the licensee is able to demonstrate ability to practice with reasonable skill and safety followed by probation, and an administrative fine from $1,000.00 to $5,000.00. Fla. Admin. Code R. 64B8-8.001(s) (November 9, 2016).  86. In its proposed recommended order, DOH requested the penalty of a reprimand, a $1,000 administrative fine, and license suspension until such time as the Respondent demonstrates her ability to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety, with such demonstration to include an evaluation by PRN, if required by PRN. This result seems reasonable and appropriate, based on the evidence in this case. However, in evaluating the Respondent and the need for monitoring, PRN should consider carefully whether drug and alcohol screening and psychotherapy is  necessary.  29  40941  RECOMMENDATION  Based on the foregoing Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law, it is RECOMMENDED that the Board of Medicine enter a final order:  1. Finding that the Respondent violated sections 456.072 (1) (hh), 458.331(1) (x), and 458.331(1)(s), Florida Statutes, as charged in the Amended Administrative Complaint;  2. Issuing a reprimand against the Respondent's medical license;  3.0 Imposing an administrative fine of $1,000.00;  4. Suspending Respondent’s medical license until such time as she demonstrates to the Board her ability to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety, with such demonstration to include an evaluation by PRN, if required by PRN; and  5. Reserving jurisdiction to impose additional terms and conditions, including a period of probation with terms and conditions to be determined by the Board at the time of  reinstatement of the Respondent’s license to practice medicine.  30 40942  DONE AND ENTERED this 8th day of January, 2018, in  Tallahassee, Leon County, Florida.  fae feat  J. PRELIMINARY STATEMENT  On August 24, 2015, the Department of Health (DOH), fileda three-count Amended Administrative Complaint against the Respondent, Grace Mary Guastella, M.D. The Complaint charged the Respondent with: Count I, violating section 456.072(1) (hh), Florida Statutes (2013), by being terminated from her contract with the Professionals Resource Network (PRN), for failing to comply with the requirements of her contract with PRN without good cause; Count II, violating section 458.331(1) (x), Florida Statutes (2013), by failing to comply with the Final Order of the Florida Board of Medicine (Board) in DOH in cases 2002-31212 and 2003-10807, by being terminated from her contract with PRN for failing to comply with requirements of her PRN contract; and Count III, violating section 458.331(1)(s), Florida Statutes (2014), by being unable to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety to patients by reason of illness or use of alcohol, narcotics, chemicals, or any other type of material or as a result of any mental or physical condition.  The Respondent disputed the allegations and requested a formal hearing. On December 17, 2015, DOH forwarded the case to DOAH for assignment to an ALJ. Russell, being duly sworn on oath, deposes and says:  1. I am an attorney at law duly authorized to practice in the State of Florida and have been active in the practice of law in Florida since March 21, 2009. My Curriculum Vitae is attached as Exhibit 1 hereto.  2. I am personally familiar with the fees usually and customarily awarded to attorneys for legal services in administrative proceedings of the kind and nature of the captioned case.  3. Iam familiar with Rule 4-1.5(b) of the Rules Regulating the Florida  Bar, and have taken such into consideration in forming my opinion in this  or  43103  matter, the factors set forth therein for the determination of reasonable attorney's fees.  4. Tam also familiar with, and have considered in forming my opinion in this matter, the Florida Supreme Court in the case of Florida Patient's Compensation Fund vs. Rowe, 472 So.2d 1145 (Fla. 1985) relating to the determination of reasonable attorney’s fees.  5. I have reviewed the file of the Department of Health (the Department) in relation to this case.  6. I have reviewed the Department's “Time Tracking System Itemized Cost by Complaint” for the case referenced herein, which is among the attachments to the Motion to Assess Costs. I have only reviewed and analyzed the time entries for the Prosecution Services Unit.  7. Based on my review of these documents, it is my understanding that the Department is seeking to recover $52,371.66 for its attorney time and other costs related to the prosecution of this case.  8. Based on the above, and on my years in legal practice and my experience in this area of legal practice, it is my opinion that the hourly  rates for the Department's prosecuting attorneys used in this case are  43104  within or below the reasonable and customary range for attorney time spent on cases of this type.  9. Based on the above, and on my years in legal practice and my experience in this area of legal practice, it is my opinion that the total number of attorney hours for which the Department of Health seeks recovery in this case is within the range of time customarily spent on cases of this type and is a reasonable total number of attorney hours for this case.  10. Based on the above, and on my years in legal practice and my experience in this area of legal practice, it is my opinion that the total amount of costs sought to be recovered for attorney time and other costs of prosecution in this case is a reasonable amount in a case of this type. 11. It is my understanding that the Department is moving to recover a total of $52,371.66 of attorney time and costs in relation to this this case. 12. Based on the above, and on my years in legal practice and my experience in this area of legal practice, it is my opinion that items of expense are reasonable for a case of this type, and that the total amount of expenses sought to be recovered in this case is a reasonable amount for  a case of this type. 43105  RO Rd  Daniel R. On March 11, 2016, at the request of the parties, jurisdiction was relinquished to DOH so the parties could pursue settlement. On May 18, 2017, the matter was again referred to DOAH and was re-opened as DOAH  case 17-2923PL.  On October 10 and 11, 2017, the Respondent filed motions and supporting legal argument to dismiss the charges or at least exclude certain evidence based on alleged violations of the federal Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). At the hearing, further argument was entertained, ruling was reserved, and evidence was taken subject to the ruling on the motions. After the hearing, the Petitioner’s response in opposition was filed, and the motions were denied.  During hearing, DOH’s Exhibits 1 through 4, 5, 9, 12, 13, and 15 were admitted into evidence without objection. DOH’s Exhibits 6 and 10 were admitted into evidence over the Respondent’s objections. DOH’s Exhibits 7 and 8 contained hearsay, but both parties waived hearsay and stipulated to their use to prove the truth of the matters asserted. Respondent’s Exhibit 1 was admitted into evidence without objection.  Prior to the hearing, DOH requested official recognition of the pertinent Board final orders and Florida Administrative Code Rule 64B8-8.001 (effective May 28, 2012). The Department is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of licensed  health care professionals pursuant to Chapters 20 and 456, Florida Statutes. Also, pursuant to Division of Administrative Hearing Chapter 28-106.214 Recordation;  (1) Responsibility for preserving the testimony at final hearings shall be that of the agency  transmitting the petition te the Division of Administrative Hearings pursuant to Sections 120.569 and 120.57, F.5., the agency whose rule is being challenged, or the agency whose action initiated the proceeding. Proceedings shall be recorded by a certified court reporter or by recording instruments.  (2) No later than 10 days prior to the final hearing, the agency shall notify the parties of  the method by which the agency will record the testimony at the final hearing. Any party to a hearing may, at its own expense, provide a certified court reporter if the agency does not. The presiding officer may provide a certified court reporter. At hearings reported by a court reporter, any party who wishes a transcript of the testimony shall order the same at its own expense. Ifa court reporter records the  proceedings, the recordation shall become the official transcript. Rulemaking Authority 14.202, 120.54(5) FS. It is overseen by an impaired practitioner consultant as described in section 456.076, Florida Statutes (2017).  6. °° PRN is designed to help practitioners with substance abuse and/or mental illness to be able to practice their professions safely. Admission to PRN.can be voluntary or ordered by the Board. Treatment for PRN participants is tailored to the participant’s needs and impairment. Often, treatment programs require psychiatric evaluations, long-term treatment, and monitoring contracts.  7. On March 14, 2005, Dr. M. Saleh evaluated the Respondent. Dr. Saleh diagnosed the Respondent with bipolar disorder, in remission, and adjustment reactions with mixed emotional features. Dr. Saleh noted that the Respondent had hypomanic tendencies during the exam.  8. Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder marked by episodes of depression, mania, or hypomania. Bipolar disorder is a chronic illness with no known cure. The occurrence of a manic or depressive episode cannot be predicted.  9. ADMINISTRATIVE COMPLAINT  Petitioner Department of Health files this Administrative Complaint before the Board of Medicine against Respondent Peter Stewart Katz, M.D., and in support thereof alleges:  1. Petitioner is the state agency charged with regulating the practice of medicine pursuant to Section 20.43, Florida Statutes; Chapter 456, Florida Statutes; and Chapter 458 Florida Statutes.  2. At all times material to this Complaint, Respondent was licensed as a medical doctor within the state of Florida, having been issued license  number ME 37959. 50. Respondent failed to have, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of having, adequate medical justification for prescribing buprenorphine to Patient M.V.-C.  51, Respondent prescribed clonazepam to Patient M.V.-C.  52. Respondent failed to have, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of having, adequate medical justification to prescribe clonazepam to Patient M.V.-C. |  53. Respondent failed to perform, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of performing, adequate follow-up related to the course of treatment with buprenorphine and/or clonazepam.  54. Patient M.V-C. possessed a blank prescription signed by Respondent.  Facts Related to Patient J.M.29  55. Onor about and between February 2, 2016, and April 12, 2016, an undercover officer posing as Patient J.M. presented to Respondent for treatment approximately two times.  56. Respondent failed to create or keep adequate medical records  documenting Patient J.M.’s two visits.  19 The facts related to Patient J.M. are contained in Department of Health Case Number 2017-06116. DOH vs. Peter Stewart Katz, M.D. Case No: 2016-11776; 2017- 06116; 2017-06630; 2017-06719; 2017-06718; 2017-06720  57. Respondent failed to obtain, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of obtaining, an adequate medical history for Patient J.M. prior to providing treatment to Patient J.M.  58. Respondent failed to perform, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of performing an adequate physical examination of Patient J.M.  59. During both visits, Patient J.M. engaged in drug-seeking behavior and asked for oxycodone using the slang term “blues.”  60. On February 2, 2016, Respondent prescribed Vicoprofen”° to Patient J.M. in exchange for payment.  61. Respondent failed to have, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of having, adequate medical justification for prescribing Vicoprofen to Patient J.M.  62. On February 2, 2016, Respondent prescribed Atenolol?! to  Patient J.M. in exchange for payment.  20 Atenolol is a beta blocker that is commonly prescribed to treat high blood pressure.  21 Vicoprofren contains hydrocodone and ibuprofen and is prescribed to treat pain. According to Section 893.03(3), Florida Statutes (2016-2017), hydrocodone, in the dosages found in Vicoprofen, is a Schedule III controlled substance that has a potential for abuse less than the substances in Schedules I and II and has a currently accepted medical use in treatment in the United States. Abuse of the substance may lead to moderate or low physical dependence or high psychological dependence.  DOH vs. Peter Stewart Katz, M.D. 11 Case No: 2016-11776; 2017-06116; 2017-06630; 2017-06719; 2017-06718; 2017-06720  63. Respondent failed to have, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of having, adequate medical justification for prescribing Atenolol to Patient J.M.  64. On or about April 12, 2016, Respondent prescribed Norco to Patient J.M. in exchange for payment.  65. Respondent failed to have, or failed to create or keep adequate, legible documentation of having, adequate medical justification for prescribing Norco to Patient J.M.  66. Respondent failed to identify a specific symptom and/or diagnosed a specific condition that warranted the prescription of controlled pain medication to Patient J.M.  67. Respondent failed to appropriately address Patient J.M.’s drug- seeking behavior.  Facts Related to the Sober Home”  68. Section 458.331(1)(t  97. Section 458.331(1)(t), Florida Statutes (2012-2017), subjects a medical doctor to discipline for committing medical malpractice as defined in Section 456.50, Florida Statutes. The board shail give great weight to the provision of Section 766.102, Florida Statutes, when enforcing this paragraph. Medical malpractice shall not be construed to require more than one instance, event, or act.  98. Section 456.50(1)(g), Florida Statutes (2013-2017), defines medical malpractice to mean the failure to practice medicine in accordance with the level or care, skill, and treatment recognized in general law related to health care licensure. Opioid drugs are addictive and subject to abuse. Section 458.331(1)(m), Florida Statutes (2012-2017), subjects a medical doctor to discipline for failing to keep legible, as defined by department rule in consultation with the board, medical records that — identify the licensed physician or the physician extender and supervising  physician by name and professional title who is or are responsible for DOH vs. Peter Stewart Katz, M.D Case No: 2016-11776; 2017- 06116; 2017- 06630; 2017- 06719; 2017-06718; 2017-06720 rendering, ordering, supervising, or billing for each diagnostic or treatment procedure and that justify the course of treatment of the patient, including, but not limited to, patient histories; examination results; test results; records of drugs prescribed, dispensed, or administered; and reports of consultations and hospitalizations.  120. Rule 64B8-9.003(2), Florida Administrative Code, provides that a licensed physician shall maintain patient medical records in English, in a legible manner and with sufficient detail to clearly demonstrate why the course of treatment was taken.  121. Rule 64B8-9.003, Florida Administrative Code, provides that the medical record should contain sufficient information to identify the patient, support the diagnosis, justify the treatment and documents the course and results of treatment accurately, by including, at a minimum, patient histories; examination ‘results; test results; records of drugs prescribed, dispensed, or administered; reports of consultations and hospitalizations; and copies of records or reports or other documentation obtained from other health care practitioners at the request of the physician and relied upon by the physician in determining the appropriate treatment  of the patient. L., a seventy three year-old female, presented to Munroe Regional Medical Center with a non- displaced closed femoral neck fracture of her right hip.  5... On or about September 3, 2005, Respondent performed a stabilization of the displaced closed femoral neck fracture of L.L.’s right hip which involved the placement of two cannulated screws across the fracture  site using closed technique under fluoroscopic guidance:  6.
